title: Introduction to var, :=, and const
content: In Go, you can declare variables and constants using `var`, `:=`, and `const`. Each has a different use case, and understanding them is essential for clean and correct Go code.

title: Using var for Variable Declaration
content:
The `var` keyword is used for declaring variables. It allows you to specify the type or let the compiler infer it.

```go
var age int = 25
var name = "Alice" // Type inferred
```

title: Using := for Short Variable Declaration
content:
`:=` is a shorthand for declaring and initializing a variable. It can only be used **inside functions**, and the type is inferred automatically.

```go
age := 25
name := "Alice"
```

title: Using const for Constants
content:
`const` is used to declare constantsâ€”values that do not change. Constants must be assigned at the time of declaration.

```go
const Pi = 3.14
const AppName = "MyApp"
```
